title: Safety Margins: Space, Speed, and Stopping
summary: Control your speed and space so you can react, brake, and stop safely in any conditions.

sections.title: Why Safety Margins Matter
sections.body: Leaving generous gaps gives you time to deal with mistakes—yours and other road users’. It’s how you stay out of the ‘no time to react’ danger zone.

sections.title: DVSA Essentials
items: Keep a two-second gap in the dry, four seconds in the wet, and up to ten seconds in snow or ice.
Rule 126: Drive at a speed that allows you to stop within the distance you can see to be clear.
Increase following distance for large vehicles, motorcycles, or when towing.

sections.title: Judging Safe Gaps
sections.body: Choose a roadside marker and say ‘Only a fool breaks the two-second rule.’ If you pass the marker before you finish speaking, you’re too close. Extend the count when conditions worsen.

sections.title: Stopping Distances
items: Thinking distance increases with speed—double your speed and your stopping distance quadruples.
Keep tyres inflated and brakes maintained to achieve the stopping distances shown in the Highway Code.
Plan ahead for downhill slopes or heavy loads; both lengthen your stopping distance.

sections.title: Adapting to Conditions
items: Rain: slow earlier, use gentle steering and braking to avoid aquaplaning.
Fog: use dipped headlights or fog lights when visibility drops below 100 m and maintain a huge gap.
Ice or snow: move off in a higher gear, accelerate gently, and keep revs low.

checklist.label: I use the two-second rule and extend it when grip is reduced.
I adjust my speed so I can stop within the distance I can see.
I adapt stopping distances for passengers, loads, and road gradients.
I have a plan for rain, fog, and icy conditions before setting off.

practiceTips.label: Marker drill
practiceTips.detail: On dual carriageways, pick every other lamppost and rehearse the two-second mantra. Notice how much space you gain when you ease off early.

practiceTips.label: Create a stopping chart
practiceTips.detail: Write out the Highway Code stopping distances and stick them near your study space. Spaced repetition helps them stick for the test.

practiceTips.label: Theo’s weather prep
practiceTips.detail: Before lessons, check the Met Office app. If grip looks low, agree a reduced-speed plan with your instructor.

questions.prompt: You’re following a lorry in heavy rain. What time gap should you leave?

options.label: Two seconds
options.explanation: Two seconds is only recommended in dry conditions.

options.label: Four seconds
options.explanation: Wet roads need at least double the dry following distance.

options.label: One second because the lorry is slow
options.explanation: Reducing the gap makes spray worse and removes your stopping space.

questions.prompt: Why should you increase your following distance at night?

options.label: Your reaction time improves in the dark
options.explanation: Reaction times are slower, not faster, when visibility is limited.

options.label: It gives more time to react when you can’t see hazards clearly
options.explanation: Longer gaps compensate for reduced visibility and glare from lights.

options.label: So you can use full beam more often
options.explanation: Full beam must be dipped for oncoming traffic regardless of distance.

questions.prompt: What’s the best action if you start to aquaplane?

options.label: Accelerate to regain control
options.explanation: Speeding up reduces grip further and prolongs the skid.

options.label: Ease off the accelerator and avoid steering sharply
options.explanation: Gently easing off lets the tyres regain contact with the road.

options.label: Brake firmly and hold the pedal down
options.explanation: Heavy braking can lock wheels and make the skid worse, even with ABS.

questions.prompt: How does a heavy load affect your stopping distance?

options.label: It reduces it because the tyres grip more
options.explanation: Extra weight lengthens stopping distance and may require lower speeds.

options.label: It increases it, so you should leave more space ahead
options.explanation: More mass means more momentum, which needs extra time and distance to stop.

options.label: It makes no difference if you have ABS
options.explanation: ABS helps steering control but cannot defy physics—leave more room.
